    Head S (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [15th March, 2003],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head S of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Mr Yeo Guat Kwang].

    Question again proposed.

    The Chairman: I would like to remind Members that the amount of time allocated for each cut includes the reply by the Ministers. Therefore, what it really means is that Members actually have much less time than the 4.6 minutes allocated for each amendment. Dr Amy Khor.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, I would like to applaud the MOM for aggressively and tirelessly launching a slew of programmes to help retrenched workers and groom Singaporeans into an adaptable workforce with portable skills.

    In fact, one of my grassroots leaders with business in China and Australia, recently remarked, half in jest, that compared to other governments in the region,

Column: 1095

we may have taken skills upgrading and retraining much too seriously. He mused cynically that perhaps the Government has done too much, so much so that when workers cannot get a job after retraining with Government funds, they blame the Government who kept nudging them to go for retraining in the first place.

    But, on a more serious note, despite the plethora of skills upgrading and retraining programmes launched, some Singaporeans at the ground have the impression that what had been done so far are ad hoc and disjointed. Some feel that the large number of schemes, as well as the multiple agencies organising these schemes, is confusing and that there is also some degree of duplication. Rightly or wrongly, the suspicion is that all the money on retraining may not have been well spent and the results less than sterling.

    For instance, are there enough job opportunities for the course participants after they complete the programme? Otherwise, some could become even more dejected. This calls for a programme of career counselling to help workers match their skills and interests with the job opportunities available.

    Have the most relevant and useful training programmes been organised? Has the training helped them find employment? What is the job retention rate of the trainees after they complete the programme? I hope the Minister can enlighten us on these questions.

    Sir, due to these issues, I am pleased that a body to further develop, promote and coordinate Continuing Education and Training for adults and their placement will be formed. The new CET body should work closely with all relevant private and public sector organisations in identifying, planning and organising the appropriate CET programmes and inculcating the habit of lifelong learning in a Singaporean workforce at all levels, including the professionals and executives who have not been spared from

Column: 1096

redundancy and retrenchments. The CET body should confine itself to policy and promotion and champion the involvement of the private sector to supply services to realise its mission. It should try to outsource as many courses as possible to the private sector who has the capability to conduct these courses and not directly compete with them in course delivery. This would prevent the CET body from becoming another behemoth that some members of the public are wary of. It would indeed be ironic if there comes a day when the CET body, which oversees training and placement of the unemployed, has to retrench employees themselves.

    The CET body should ensure that minimum standards are complied with. Finally, it should also track the success and effectiveness of all programmes implemented, benchmark itself against an internationally accepted set of educational Key Performance Indicators (KPI) and report these periodically.

    The Chairman: Dr Gan See Khem is not here. Ms Irene Ng.

    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Sir, let me start by relating the experience of a man who has been retrenched three times and he is only 39 years old. His first retrenchment was in 1982. He worked as a pipe fitter and he got retrenched after about 11/2 years. Then, he worked as a marine assistant in Jurong Island and after 13 years, he was retrenched. His third retrenchment was last week, from a paint factory where he worked as a warehouse assistant.

    You would think that, after being retrenched twice, he would have been better steeled for his last one. But no. For him, his last retrenchment was the most traumatic. This was because of the way the exercise was conducted. He went to work, like any normal day. Then, after lunch, a dozen of them were asked to go to the boardroom, and they were told that they were retrenched. Just like that. They were given their cheques on the spot, told to pack up, return anything that belongs to the office and leave that very

Column: 1097

day. He was so upset that he threw his company uniform into the dustbin in front of his supervisor.

    Sir, his experience holds some lessons. No, not only that you have to be prepared to be retrenched several times in your working life, but also that some companies just lack the experience and knowledge on how to conduct retrenchments in a humane and proper way.

    With retrenchments on the rise in Singapore, I feel that it is necessary to lay down some guidelines on what constitute good industrial relations practice on conducting retrenchments.

    Sir, we do not want to make it so hard for companies to retrench in so hard a way that would affect the flexibility of our labour market and our attractiveness for investment. But we cannot allow it to be so freewheeling that companies can discard workers like so many expired canned food on a shelf.

    An example of a good retrenchment practice is that conducted by Beecham Pharmaceuticals in 1996, where it gave about one year's notice to staff of its impending retrenchment exercise. The time allowed them to make alternative plans regarding their financial commitments and to look for a job.

    Indeed, Beecham and the union, the Chemical Industries Employees' Union, arranged for staff to attend courses during their working hours. Nearer the retrenchment date, the company provided counselling and even allowed its workers time-off to go for job interviews. By doing this, it treated the departing employees with dignity and respect, and kept morale high among the remaining employees.

    A question that arises from the recent PSA retrenchment is that it is an example of a good retrenchment exercise or a bungled one. People are divided on this issue. Some say yes, this is a good example, because PSA management made a general announcement on the estimated numbers to be retrenched on 17th February and gave a notice period

Column: 1098

of about one month so that unions could start formal negotiations with management to work out a fair package. This was better than to spring it suddenly on the unions and workers, which would then have no time to consult each other and to find ways to help the workers.

    Others, including some in the media, say no. The media reported that many workers had been anxious to know who would be retrenched and that morale was down because of the uncertainty.

    The Chairman: Ms Irene Ng, you are nearing the end of your speaking time.

    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong: This led PSA to expedite the process and conclude the negotiations as soon as possible. But it raises the question of what makes a good practice in terms of giving a notice of retrenchment. How long should it be?

    To clarify the matter, I would urge the Manpower Ministry, together with its tripartite partners, to work out guidelines on how to deal with retrenchments, including the matter of giving appropriate notice. This could form a Code of Practice on good industrial relations for retrenchment exercises.

    Assoc. Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang (Nominated Member): Sir, I would like to add on to what hon. Member, Irene Ng, has said. As retrenchment is generally a painful and traumatic experience for affected employees, it is the manner in which employees are retrenched and the attitude of some employers that I wish to raise.

    As Ms Irene Ng has informed us, some organisations are very caring. They go beyond their statutory responsibilities in providing whatever retrenchment benefits are required of them to the employees. They take pains to inform and prepare the workers. They arrange for MOM and the trade union to be present at the workplace during the period when retrenchment notices were served, to help with alternative employment opportunities and to offer comfort and support. They make referrals to social service organisations, for example, Family Service Centres, for

Column: 1099

those who need counselling and advice on personal and family matters. A few conscientious employers would even invite Family Service Centres or other social service organisations to the workplace during that period to offer on-site information, referrals and counselling service to their retrenched staff. Unfortunately, as we have just heard, the majority of retrenchment exercises do not go that smoothly. Only a handful of the employers bother to provide such an arrangement.

    Sir, the anxiety and despondency of being retrenched, especially for those who have heavy family responsibilities to worry about, can affect their social, psychological health. .Hence, bringing in the assistance of professionally qualified social workers and counsellors, for instance, as part of the overall process during their retrenchment exercise is to be strongly encouraged. The helping professionals can listen to the employees and offer them comfort. They can work out with the retrenched employees on how to mobilise social support and community resources and how to make necessary changes and adjustments in their lives. In this way, the unwelcome blow of retrenchment can be mitigated and a heavy burden lightened. This would also help boost the psychological state of mind of retrenched persons and help provide the necessary motivation, among other matters, for them to press on with finding jobs or to go for training.

    Sir, my query to the Minister then is: how can MOM encourage more employers to provide counselling and social service assistance to their retrenched staff, either through their own human resource department or by inviting Family Service Centres and the CDCs, for example, to be on site at the workplace, during the time when the retrenchment exercise is on?

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, I am concerned that our structural unemployment is on a rising trend. According to the World Development Report 2001, our structural unemployment stands at

Column: 1100

17.7%, as compared to Korea's 2.5% and the United States' 8.7%.

    The percentage of structural unemployment is rising among the highest educated segment of the workforce as well. According to the IPS report, the share of secondary educated structural unemployment increased to nearly 30% as at 2001. What is more worrying is that the share of the higher educated, which means post-secondary, diploma and degree holders who were structurally unemployed, increased by more than three-fold, from 7% to nearly 24% between 1986 and 2001.

    I believe this is partly due to our education system being too rigidly or artificially designed to meet the needs of MNCs in the past. Many graduates cannot find jobs that match their training as those MNCs who need their knowledge have left Singapore. It is ironic that while our Government is constantly stressing on producing high-value added products and services, high-value added human resource could not find any jobs.

    There are also people who think that the foreign talent policy is another factor contributing to the high rate of unemployment. These so called foreign talents are merely cheap replacements for our high-educated workforce. Many people also started to wonder whether they have been short-changed by these so-called foreign talents.

    The Government has been talking about training and retraining. My question is: how successful has this strategy been in solving the structural unemployment problem? Maybe the Government should be reminded that skilled workers are also facing a rising trend in structural unemployment, from 10% in 1986 to more than 30% in 2001, as shown in the Institute of Policy Studies' report. Just blaming workers for not accepting jobs of lower pay or status will not help in the long run. The social and economic cost of workers having their potential under-utilised will be huge in the long run for a small resource-scarce economy like Singapore.

Column: 1101



    I am also concerned about the social and psychological impact of prolonged structural unemployment. I would like to know whether the Government has commissioned any studies on the social and psychological impact of structural unemployment. According to statistics, again provided by IPS report, the percentage of older workers, from age 40-49, rose from 17% in 1984 to 40% in 2001. The social and psychological impact on this group of workers, who probably has the most heavy burden of their life cycle with children to support, would be great and far-reaching. It would lead to problems like mental instability due to stress, stress on marital status, marital relations, social polarisation between the haves and have-nots, reduce social cohesion, etc.

    Sir, I would like to know what is the Government's assessment of the seriousness of structural unemployment. Besides urging people to lower their expectation, to sail through the rough waters, training and retraining, etc, are there any other plans to help mitigate the pain of those suffering under the situation of structural unemployment?
11.15 am

    The Minister for Manpower (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Sir, I thank the many hon. Members who have spoken on the manpower challenges, employment market and job assistance measures and also on continuing education and training.

    Before addressing the specific queries raised by hon. Members, I would like to make some general comments to put in perspective the situation and challenges confronting us today. First and foremost, the poor employment market reflects the weak global economy. Major economies such as the US, the European countries and Japan are down. We cannot expect to be immune from the global downturn. There is also a radical shift in the global environment. Globalisation and the relentless pursuit of corporate competitiveness are pushing companies to be more mobile. They scour the world for locations that can offer them a

Column: 1102

competitive edge in terms of cost, productivity, infrastructure and talent. Previously, labour-intensive operations such as manufacturing of toys, radios and TVs were transferred to the less- developed countries. Later on, more sophisticated products, such as disk drives and computers, followed. But the current round of globalisation is seeing even skilled and knowledge type of jobs moving offshore as well. This is not just happening in the United States or the European countries, but also affecting Singapore, with the emergence of China and India as major economic competitors. With the Internet, knowledge tasks can be undertaken or done almost anywhere in the world. Many MNCs are shifting their back-room operations and even call centres to India. Others are shifting to China and eastern European countries which have ample highly skilled, well-educated workers willing to work at competitive salaries in areas like chip design, software engineering, even auditing financial statements and drafting architectural plans.

    Singapore has to compete for investments and jobs in this global environment. To remain competitive, we have to move up the value-added and technology ladder. This is not the first time that Singapore has had to change gear. From making shoes and garments, we went into making hair-dryers, typewriters and radios. Later on, we went into printed circuit boards, disk drives, semi-conductors and precision-engineering. Today, Singapore continues to attract investments in growth industries such as specialty chemicals, high value electronics products such as network storage devices, advanced display devices, photonics, digital media, and biomedical industries.

    In short, Sir, we have stayed ahead and remained competitive because we have successfully adapted our economy to suit global trends. What is different today is that the pace of restructuring is accelerating and so we need to adjust faster than before. And this time, Sir, there are more competitors in the market. Displacement, or job losses, is also affecting the entire spectrum of workers, from lower-skilled blue-collar workers to professionals, managers and executives.

Column: 1103



    So how do we address the concerns of those who are vulnerable to economic restructuring and to structural unemployment, as Mr Low had just mentioned? First, we must have more investments, so that new jobs can be created. To do this, we must transform Singapore into an even more attractive location for businesses that come here because they can leverage on our excellent economic infrastructure. That is the strategic thrust of the Economic Review Committee's Report. And, Sir, Singapore is attractive. Despite the gloomy global economic environment last year, EDB attracted $9 billion worth of fixed assets investments in manufacturing and $2 billion worth of business spending in services. And, as the Minister for Trade and Industry told us on Saturday, these investments will add 20,000 new jobs when operational.

    Sir, EDB's investment promotion efforts will receive a boost with our network of FTAs with different countries, especially the upcoming FTAs with the United States. For example, recently ST-Microelectronics - by the way, "ST" is not "Singapore Technologies", it is a European company - just announced that it would invest S$436 million over the next three years to expand its semiconductor production capacity in Singapore. ST Micro expects this to create some 800 new jobs. Another company, AFPD's Liquid Crystal Display plant, launched at the end of last year, is an example of the advanced display industry which we believe has growth potential. AFPD's investment of some S$3.14 billion over the initial two years is expected to generate 700 jobs. These and other investments will create many skilled jobs and also some unskilled ones along the way.

    At the same time, IE Singapore is helping our companies to seek out new markets and export opportunities. As our companies grow their businesses abroad, they will have to build up management capabilities at home to help to run the business in the region. This will create

Column: 1104

more jobs for our professionals and managers.

    To bring more investments here, we need workers with the right skill sets for the jobs. If workers lack skills or if they cannot pick up the relevant skills, they will not be employable. Then we will suffer growing structural unemployment. So, the answer is in skills upgrading. Many hon. Members - Mr Yeo Guat Kwang, Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon, Mdm Halimah Yacob, Mr Heng Chee How, Mr Ong Ah Heng and Dr Amy Khor - have spoken in support of Government's effort to upgrade the skills of our workers or retrain them for the new jobs. I thank all the hon. Members for their endorsement.

    Sir, skills upgrading is not new to our workforce. It is not new to Singapore. As all Members know, the Government has been promoting skills upgrading for decades. Over the years, we have, in fact, established a very strong system of employer-based training in Singapore. Members will recall that we set up the Skills Development Fund in 1979. Since then, the Skills Development Fund has supported some 8 million training places for our workers. That has kept our workers productive and competitive in the past two decades.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang pointed out that we should use the present slack period to prepare our workers for recovery. I agree wholeheartedly. In FY 2001, the Government contributed $500 million as a one-off payment to the Skills Development Fund (SDF) to sustain its effort to train the workers.

    The Manpower 21 Plan launched in 1999 highlighted the importance of promoting lifelong learning. Since then, we have achieved some success with new programmes introduced to build up skills in various segments of the workforce.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang, and I believe Dr Amy Khor, also asked how many workers were helped through this programme. We have exceeded the 5-year target of 100,000 training places under the Skills Redevelopment Programme administered

Column: 1105

by the NTUC. Over 150,000 people have been trained in IT skills under the National IT Literacy Programme and also the Infocomm Competency Programme. Over 20,000 people have been trained under the WorkSkills Training Programme. And, over 4,800 professionals have been trained under the Strategic Manpower Conversion Programme and Self-Employment Training Programme. This does not include professionals, managers, executives and technicians who were trained under different programmes run by EDB, MAS, Infocomm Development Authority and IE Singapore.

    Sir, the annual Lifelong Learning Festival has also reached out to some 75,000-100,000 Singaporeans each year. But more can be done. The Economic Review Committee recommended that a Continuing Education and Training statutory board be formed to provide more comprehensive and effective national Continuing Education and Training. Government has accepted this recommendation. The Ministry of Manpower will establish a statutory board to focus on CET and employment facilitation by the end of this year. The mission of this new statutory board is to enhance employability and competitiveness of Singaporean workers. It is to prepare our workers, young and old, skilled and unskilled, professionals and blue-collar, for the restructured economy. I thank the many hon. Members including Mr Ahmad Magad, Mr Seng Han Thong, Mdm Halimah Yacob and others for their comments and suggestions for the CET statutory board. We will be considering all of these ideas and suggestions in the months ahead as we go about setting up the statutory board.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo and Miss Irene Ng seem particularly worried that when the ERC Report, or my Ministry officials, or even myself mentioned "workers", we are only thinking of blue-collar workers. Let me assure all of them, once and for all, that when we use the term "worker" or "workforce", we use it in the broadest sense. We use it in an all-embracing manner. We are all workers - working for our families, for Singapore - regardless

Column: 1106

of the actual job that we are engaged in. However, we will still need to prioritise and target our training assistance. As Mdm Halimah pointed out on Saturday, the lower-skilled workers are more vulnerable to structural unemployment. Yes, we are seeing structural unemployment, and growing unemployment even among the professionals, managers and executives, but the lower-skilled and lower-educated are by far the most vulnerable. So they needed a little extra help.

    Sir, briefly, I see the statutory board doing the following:

    (1) promote workforce skills upgrading;

    (2) build a comprehensive Continuing Education and Training infrastructure;

    (3) enable sustained Continuing Education and Training with employers' involvement and support;

    (4) develop the Continuing Education and Training and Human Resource industries;

    (5) last, but not least, regulate the standards of Continuing Education and Training.

    Sir, the statutory board's objective is very specific - the employability of our workers. But its mandate is broad because it will serve the mainstream of adult workers, not just the lower skilled or the unemployed. It will reach out to our workers, including the professionals, managers and executives. I see it helping these groups to meet their skills and job needs through:

    (1) continuing skills upgrading for all levels of the workforce, including professionals and executives;

    (2) helping our workers to develop new skills so that they can get jobs in growth industries;

    (3) providing employment assistance programmes which will be packaged together with skills training for new jobs and, in some cases, with some career counselling and guidance.

Column: 1107



    Mrs Yu-Foo, Mr Ahmad Magad and several other hon. Members have highlighted the need to strengthen the nexus between training and industry needs. In particular, Mrs Yu-Foo would like to see better planning to train workers for incoming industries so that jobs would not be taken by foreign workers because Singaporeans are not available. This will be the statutory board's modus operandi. This will be how we will approach the task. The statutory board will collaborate closely with the EDB and all industries to ensure that training programmes will meet the industries' needs, including the needs of the new investments coming into Singapore. It is important that we identify the current skill gaps and future skill needs of the industries, so that training programmes are industry-relevant. Besides providing appropriate pre-employment training in our ITEs, polytechnics and universities, we should also have continuing education and training for workers to equip them with job specific skills for the new jobs that are being created.
11.30 am

    To address Mr Ong Ah Heng's concern about training that is not recognised by employers, we have already established the National Skills Recognition System, which provides for portable skill certification. The Continuing Education and Training statutory board will certainly promote skills certification and recognition to enhance workers' portability and also employability of our workers who have undergone such training.

    Ms Irene Ng suggested that we should make sure that trained workers are given jobs. She suggested getting employers to guarantee to employ the workers after they have gone for training. I understand the disappointment suffered by a diligent worker who had invested much time and effort to upgrade himself but, at the end, could not get a job. It is very disappointing. No doubt, this has happened, especially when our job market is shrinking. I agree with her, and that is

Column: 1108

why we have already started to introduce Place-and-Train programmes. In other words, the unemployed is placed with a company and after the company signs him on as an employee, that is when we send him for training. After the training, he goes back to the job. Examples are the Aerospace Reskilling for Operations Programme, Call Centre Programme, Hospitality Programme - hospitality in our hotel industry - and, the recently announced, Intellectual Property Professional Programme. All these programmes are place-and-train programmes. This requires participating employers to sign up the worker before they are sent for training. My Ministry pays for most of the cost of training and also provides full-time trainees with allowances.

    But even with the best of intentions, we still encounter disappointments. For instance, in the Hospitality Programme in the hotel sector, in one case, 62 out of the 81 who were offered jobs accepted. Out of those who accepted, a full 40% left their jobs within three months after training. They cited unwillingness to work shifts, dislike for working on public holidays and even dislike for the place of work. We have spent so much money to train them, paid for the training course and, in some cases, even gave them allowances. So, maybe I should take Ms Irene Ng's suggestion seriously. Members may remember that on Saturday, she suggested the "money back guarantee". Maybe I should take her seriously. employability and also enable them to fend for themselves through self-employment, part-time work and flexible work arrangements. This group is growing by the day.     The Minister of State for Manpower (Dr Ng Eng Hen): Sir, let me thank Members for their suggestions to assist retrenched and unemployed Singaporeans as well as cogent recommendations to improve our unemployment situation. Sir, the points they have brought up are indeed important, as many analysts predict that this more disruptive economic climate may persist for some time. In other words, how globalisation will pan out, the backlashes, how our economic conditions would be, even following the impending war if there is one, remain uncertain. These are fundamentally turbulent times and we are not quite sure when visibility will improve and what the climate or the scenarios will be, after visibility has improved. Therefore, it would be important for us to examine our fundamentals for policy decisions.

    Our responses to existing challenges are underpinned by prevailing principles

Column: 1139

and, if you like, philosophies. Through our meetings with other Government officials and comparison with other systems, we consistently subject our beliefs to scrutiny. Singapore, if you believe in equal commiseration, is not the only country facing unemployment. Others have had it much tougher and for a longer time. Recently, I led a delegation to some European cities to study how they address their problems of unemployment and assistance. The trip shed much light and I will share some main take-away lessons.

    The first lesson is that temporary assistance schemes, indiscriminately applied and started with the best of intentions, degenerate very quickly into permanent schemes and hurt the overall economy. Please note that these are systems in developed countries run by seasoned bureaucrats with their armies of think-tanks and policy makers. Even with their vast intellectual resources and the realisation that change has to be made urgently, they find it a stupendous task to ameliorate, let alone reverse, the increase in spending on assistance related to unemployment. So, in some countries, they end up spending as much as 3% of their GDP on social assistance schemes. This is more than three-quarters of our Education budget, which caters for 550,000 people, but they spent it on social assistance schemes. Their corresponding cost of government is about 40% of GDP, compared with 19% in Singapore currently. GST, in these countries, is in the double digits and corresponding marginal personal and corporate tax rates twice that of ours, as they have to raise by taxes and revenues 40 cents just to generate one dollar of turnover. Predictably, these countries lose their competitiveness and the negative spiral begins, and continues. Sir, if we ever choose to follow suit, this will be a load that will sink us all. Perhaps, some MPs might say that we can benefit from the wisdom of hindsight and avoid the excesses that these economies have been encumbered with. Are we so certain? Should we venture into the water when there are many

Column: 1140

signs telling us to beware of the strong undercurrents?

    There have been a number of suggestions, both from the speakers during the Committee of Supply and the Budget debate, in terms of Government loans, retrenchment, endowment, and `heed' funds. Sir, they are well-meaning, but I would caution, eg, loan funds and retrenchment funds, how would Government enforce repayments if we use their houses as collaterals? For borrowers who are at default, Government would not be keen to repossess their houses. Alternatively, if we allow members to use their own or future CPF funds, they would deplete their retirement savings. I would caution us moving that way.

    Like MPs who have weekly meet-the-people sessions, I share Members' concern over the plight of retrenched workers, and our more targeted approach to assist them is the right one. We have many benefits as enumerated by Deputy Prime Minister Lee as well as financial assistance schemes in our CDCs and CCCs. Deputy Prime Minister Lee spoke on the sensitivity of our grassroots schemes. We should not underestimate the effectiveness and value that our various grassroots schemes have.

    My CCC welfare committee, like yours, I am sure, is a veritable fount of local knowledge. I have one particular lady who has lived in the estate for over 20 years. Sometimes, I almost believe that she knows every elderly or down-and-out constituent. She knows, for example, in detail what cars their children drive, what they eat and how much they eat. Occasionally, she will bring hardship cases to my MPS with specific details of family feuds and how the appellant has suffered. Other times, she will disagree on certain persons that we have chosen to help. "They use the money to treat their friends at coffee shops", she tells me. Or, "her son drives a big car and they are still getting PA allowance." Their local knowledge in our community-based assistance scheme is invaluable. They serve as brakes or lubricants, to be appropriately applied.

Column: 1141

And, these schemes are better than any other bureaucratic schemes I have seen today.

    Secondly, we should be prudent that in our efforts to help those retrenched, we do not unwittingly undermine the efforts of the willing. What do I mean? Yes, the unemployment rate was 4.2% in the last quarter. Let us not forget that 96% of those that have jobs will themselves to work. Sir, work is not fun and glamorous every day. There are days for every person, and I am sure for all Members in this House, where you choose to work whether you feel you like it or not. There is no fanfare or stardust outside your door. It is a conscious choice we make.

    I mentioned my study trip and the lessons learned, and one particular poignant vignette was obtained from a senior official who has been helping the unemployed for decades. He has lots of experience as their unemployment rates were in the teens for many years. Those requiring employment assistance, he has concluded from years of experience, fall into three groups. The first group has skills and attitude, and are self-starters. Many of them get information on their own and need little, if any help, to get re-employed. The second group needs training indeed for new skills to get jobs. The third group, he graphically portrays, needs to be reminded that they have an interview the next day. Indeed, officers in his agency actually call on the day of interview to wake this third group of members to remind them! He did not recount his conclusions with bitter cynicism or disillusionment. He said so with a matter-of-fact tone and with a sense of acceptance and equanimity. His realistic appraisal would help his organisation to be more effective in their role, he added.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang has asked what has Government done to create enough jobs. He has said whether they were the right types of jobs. Sir, other Members have expressed, despite jobs being present, as Dr Wang Kai Yuen has said, whether Government has underestimated the extent of the problem. In these times, it would be prudent for us to look

Column: 1142

inwards as well as outwards. Our figures are very robust. They are from figures that we take from about 25,000 households and they are trend lines as well which convince us that they are indeed robust. In fact, last year, our local employment grew by 1.3%. It did not shrink. Yes, there was a net loss in unemployment, the amount of which was due to foreigners leaving, both with Work Permit and Employment Pass, but our local employment grew by 1.3%. Should we start saying that there are not enough jobs, that the situation is imperfect? Where should we place our efforts and resources? Do we deprive those who have a good attitude or do help those who place themselves `furthest from the job market' - this was another term we learned on this trip? Do we pile even higher the table for those who feel that the existing food on their table is not appetising? Do we take away food from the table for those who by their own efforts feed themselves? There are no easy answers, but we cannot be naive. It will undo us. In all our asking and angst, we should first get wisdom.

    The third lesson was that those who fail to plan and provide for the future have planned to fail. I know it sounds axiomatic but, nonetheless, remains true. Governments all around the globe are grappling with the adequacy of pension funds as life-expectancy increases and populations age. First generation Singaporeans build up substantial reserves which have created stable conditions and a strong currency. In October 2001, Deputy Prime Minister Lee indicated that the Government would consider the withdrawal of CPF in extremis, but now is not the time. The recent ERC has concluded that the CPF system should be refocused on the three basic needs of retirement, housing and healthcare. And, the CPF system stay focused.

    Sir, there are jobs available. Yes, workers have to adjust their mindsets and expectations but it can be done. My Minister mentioned that for year 2002, 72% of those retrenched in the first three quarters of the year found employment by December. Seven out of ten Singaporeans

Column: 1143

proved that it can be done by finding work six months after retrenchment. Therefore, our approach has been that we should enable those who want to remain employable through reskilling or to counsel them in job opportunities. This would increase the incentive for more people to re-enter the workforce, particularly to do part-time work. However, we would not want to completely waive the contribution requirement for this group, nor waive the employer's CPF contributions.

    There is a need to strike a balance between building up sufficient CPF funds for old age, on one hand, and encouraging more people to enter the workforce. However, I agree that there is room for review, if need be, as to where the base salary level should be. And I am also not keen on this idea because I think there is more to it than just fundamentally CPF contributions. For example, our PJTP scheme that my Minister spoke about provides very generous wage adjustments, if you like. We sponsor 50% of those salaries in the first six months and, even with those generous schemes, people are not hiring. I suspect that many employers are reluctant to hire because of the uncertainty. First came September

Column: 1144

11, then the current Iraq crisis. Until visibility improves, we will have to stick to this situation and not adjust precipitously.

    Mr Ahmad Magad has suggested that we increase efficiencies by formulating or formalising contract manpower industry. He will be happy to note that indeed it has already happened without any of our measures and that there is flexibility in our labour market. In 2002, 70% of contract workers found employment through this industry.
